Event Summary: The U.S. House approves the Colorado River Drought Plan aimed at improving water conservation.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Tribal Nations, All Water Users
Comments: Plan is approved by house, still awaiting final approval.

Newspaper: The Associated Press State & Local Wire
Article Title: Interior works with tribes on Arizona water deal
Event Summary: After decades of disagreement between stakeholders, the DOI hopes to bring the Little Colorado River Settlement before Congress in an effort to recognize Navajo and Hopi Nations' claims to water rights. However, while the Hopi Nation approves the settlement terms, the Navajo Nation holds back final approval.
Stakeholders: Tribal Nations, Federal Government, State Government, Agriculture
Comments: Interaction is intertribal and also between tribes and federal/state reps + DOI. Tribes halting settlement approval because of unfullfilled requests.

Article Title: Navajo against suspending San Juan River water rights
Event Summary: A group of Republican state legislators ask the New Mexico Supreme Court to suspend an eight-year-old water rights agreement with the Navajo Nation and tribal leaders are strongly opposed.
Stakeholders: State Government, Tribal Nations, Irrigation Districts, Agriculture
Comments: NM submits formal disapproval of settlement.

Article Title: Gila River tribe is key player in bid for a long-term plan
Event Summary: Governor Lewis speaks at the Central Arizona Water Conservation District meeting and stresses that the Gila River Indian Community remains committed to seek an acceptable drought contingency plan that does not erase previous water rights settlements. Negotiations remain tense due to disagreements in how water cutbacks should be distributed among agriculture and tribal communities.
Stakeholders: Tribal Nations, Irrigation Districts, Agriculture, Local Government, State Government, All Water Users
Comments: Event is the CAWC meeting where the Gov. insists that resolution will not come unless GRIC's needs are heard and balanced with local ag.

Article Title: Navajo Generating Station closure leaves questions of water ownership
Event Summary: With the Navajo Generating Station closing, the Navajo Nation claims the right to use the water formally used to operate the station as well as the rest of Arizona's water from the Upper CRB, stating that the history of discussions around that water indicates that it belongs to the Nation. The right to the water will be decided through settlement or adjudication.
Stakeholders: Tribal Nations, Industry, State Government, Local Government
Comments: Navajo Nation's claims remain in disagreement with local off-reservation ag and municipalities.

Article Title: Drought plan for Colorado River studied by Congress
Event Summary: Representatives from all seven CRB states tesitfied before the Sucommittee on Water, Oceans and Wildlife detailing years of negotiations that went into forging the drought contingency plan that will be the operational foundation of the Colorado River through 2026.
Stakeholders: All Water Users, State Government
Comments: Multiple stakeholders involved in testifying before Congress. Talks of negotiations and compromises made during drought contingency planning.

Article Title: Environmentalists, feds and Utahns agree Dont send Green River water to Colorado
Event Summary: At a Utah Board of Water Resources hearing, various groups advise rejecting a petition by a Colorado businessman to divert 55,000 acre-feet of water from the Green River to Colorado's Front Range. Some fear the proposal would exacerbate intersate tensions over how the Colorado River water is shared.
Stakeholders: Environmentalists, State Government, Federal Government, All Water Users
Comments: Disagreement between various groups and business interests. Fear of out-of-state transfers.

Article Title: Free water available for areas of Needles with prior perfected rights
Event Summary: Needles, CA residents are the first to sign a contract with the Bureau of Reclamation to claim their prior perfected rights. Neighbors within each area must agree on an equitable plan for distribution of the water.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, Citizens
Comments: Negotiations and approval between BoR and citizen groups.

Article Title: The Colorado River, an old law and Utah's scarce water supply
Event Summary: The Porcupine Ridge Ranch in Routt County, Colorado, voluntarily reduces its consumptive use of its water rights and fallows 1941 acres of its irrigated hay fields. In exchange, the ranch will recieve up to $421, 650 as part of the Colorado River System Conservation Program.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, Agriculture
Comments: Voluntary reductions in consumptive use following BoR program

Article Title: Shortage to result in loss of $66 million for farmers in Pinal; Move to Tier 1 likely declared Sunday
Event Summary: For the first time since the Colorado River Compact, the BoR is expected to declare a Tier 1 water shortage. Farmers and ranchers who depend on surface water from the Central Arizona Project are expected to lose $66 million in crop sales and the area is expected to lose $104 million in county economy.
Stakeholders: Tribal Nations, Agriculture, Local Government, Irrigation Districts, Federal Government
Comments: Tension being felt between BoR and agriculture as large economic loss looms as a result of shortage declaration.

Article Title: No solid plans for Powell, Mead
Event Summary: With historically low levels in both Lake Powell and Lake Mead, stakeholders agree that more must be done soon to cut water use far more than what has been done to date. The BoR and DOI look at what's next as conservation measures fall short.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Agriculture, All Water Users
Comments: Stakeholders are working together to conserve, some cautiously optimistic while some pessimistic, but all agree on finding alternative ways to conserve.

Article Title: PVACD vows to protect local waters after Carlsbad request
Event Summary: Carlsbad Irrigation District (CID) requests to have Pecos River water usage deicded by state officials on the basis of priority rights. If approved, members of the Pecos Valley Artesian Conservancy District in Chaves and Eddy counties could be asked to reduce usage or refrain from using allotted rights until the CID obtains all of the water it is legally allowed to use for the year.
Stakeholders: State Government, Irrigation Districts, Conservation District, Agriculture, All Water Users
Comments: Agricultural users voicing slight worries about potential call of priority water rights by CID.

Article Title: Arizona joins Colorado River drought plan
Event Summary: Arizona agrees to sign the Colorado River drought contingency plan and join six other states and Mexico in voluntarily taking less water from the Colorado River.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, Agriculture, All Water Users
Comments: Arizona signs and joins in cooperation with other CRB states and Mexico.

Article Title: Trump signs drought plan to save Colorado River water
Event Summary: President Trump signs a bill authorizing the BoR to carry out the Colorado River Drought Contingency Plan.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, All Water Users, State Government
Comments: President signs bill enabling BoR to implement plan - all states in agreement.

Article Title: How Interior's $1M grant helps avoid 'catastrophic' Great Salt Lake wetlands issues
Event Summary: The DOI approves a $1 million dollar grant for a Ducks Unlimited-led project aimed at fortifying the dike system and enhancing the peoductivity of wetlands at Ogden Bay Waterfowl Management Area near the Great Salt Lake.
Stakeholders: State Government, Environmental Groups, Federal Government
Comments: Ducks unlimited proposal granted by DOI

Article Title: Colorado's stream management planning watered down by agriculture
Event Summary: A report is released that asserts that stream management plans (SMPs) for non-consumptive use completed across Colorado have been "taken over" by agricultural insterests. The process has proved to be problematic for environmental and recreation interests whose roles were intended to be enhanced through the SMP process.
Stakeholders: Agriculture, Environmental Groups, State Government, Recreation
Comments: Event was release of report and findings of discrepancies between ag and environmental/recreation interests.

Article Title: Decision day on water pact
Event Summary: The Navajo Tribal Council considers a landmark agreement with the state of Arizona that would secure the tribe's claims to a share of the water form the lower Colorado River, quantify available GW, and propose infrastructure projects to deliver the water to locations on and off the reservation. This deal would negate a previous lawsuit with Arizona and avoiding costly litigation. While many are in agreement, several tribal members feel left out of the loop, oppose the plan, and pressure Council to reject it, claiming that its approval would mean settling for too little water and that infrastructure projects to actually deliver the water would take years to complete.
Stakeholders: Navajo Nation, Hopi Tribe, State Government, All Water Users
Comments: Event is voicing of opposition from tribal members of approval of the plan and tribal members feeling left out of the loop. This event highlights conflict between state and tribal government well as between tribal members and Council.

Article Title: Anglers make short film to protest 'Million' pipeline DECK: Project would send water from Flaming Gorge to Denver
Event Summary: Trout Unlimited releases a short film protesting a plan to take billions of gallons of water each year from Flaming Gorge and send it to Colorado via a 501-mile pipeline. The film highlights the environmental and economic harm opponents say will occur if the plan is approved.
Stakeholders: Environmental Groups, NGO, State Government, Federal Government, Recreation, Agriculture, Industry, All Water Users
Comments: Event is release of the film highlighting contention between environmental interest groups and industry/state government.

Article Title: Drought metrics paint a bleak picture for Southwest
Event Summary: Colorado State University's Colorado Water Center releases a forecast for higher temperatures, lower soil moisture, lower precicipitation, and lower streamflows across the entire Colorado River Basin.
Stakeholders: All Water Users
Comments: No stakeholder interaction present, release of scientific findings

Article Title: As Lake Powell's water level falls, there's no backup plan
Event Summary: A federal forecast is released that projects a 23-27% chance that Lake Powell will fall below the "minimum power pool" of 3,490 feet between 2023-2026, triggering a shut off of Glen Canyon Dam's hydropower generators. Western Area Power Administration asserts that a plan is being developed with federal and public stakeholders in case of threshold breach while the BoR explores strategies for keeping the lake above the threshold. The Navajo Tribal Utility Authority and irrigation districts criticize the lack of planning from WAPA.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, Navajo Nation, Tohono O'Odham Nation, Pascua-Yaqui Tribe, Ak-Chin Indian Community, Gila River Indian Community, Private Utility, Irrigation Districts, Local Government

Article Title: 2020 delivers setbacks for long-planned Western water projects
Place: Lake Powell, Lake Mead, Gila River
Event Summary: Several proposals to divert water in New Mexico, Nevada and Utah run up again significant legal, financial and political roadblocks. Environmnetal groups cheat the setbacks. Examples include the Gila River Diversion Project, the Las Vegas Pipeline Project, the Lake Powell Pipeline Project,
Stakeholders: Environmental Groups, Gila River Indian Community, Agriculture, Federal Government, State Government, Business, All Water Users

Article Title: Utah's water forecast: Thirsty times are a-brewin'
Event Summary: Ranchers, farmers, and county officials work with the Utah Division of Water Rights on a new task force to reach consensus on a host of water allocation and supply issues.
Stakeholders: Agriculture, Local Government, State Government
Comments: Event is formation of new task force. No mention of tribal stakeholders.

Article Title: With future uncertain, Colorado shields its water
Event Summary: The Colorado Water Conservation Board releases a strategic document pledging to provide downstream states every gallon they're entitled to, but not more. The plan will propose legislation. The plan draws statements of agreement from California water users and Arizona State reps.
Stakeholders: State Government, All Water Users, Agriculture, Development, Recreation, Private Utility
Comments: Event is release of strategic draft which draws approval from state and municipal stakeholders.

Article Title: Reservoirs almost full after wet winter
Event Summary: After a couple of wet winters, runoff from rain and snow across the mountains of Arizona fills reservoirs nearly to capacity along the Verde and Salt Rivers.
Stakeholders: All Water Users, Private Utility, Recreation
Comments: Event has no major effects on stakeholder interactions. Event was during the height of the COVID pandemic/crisis.

Article Title: Scientists say the Great Salt Lake is disappearing, but could Utah residents save it?
Event Summary: A new study is published stating that the Great Salt Lake has shrunk to half its historic size. Most of the decline can be attributed to human water use. Scientists call for collaborative consensus among stakeholders, increased conservation projects and less water development.
Stakeholders: All Water Users, Agriculture, Local Government, Environmentalists, Mining, Development
Comments: Event is the release of the report which includes calls to collaborative action.

Article Title: Is Colorado River going through megadrought?; Basin affected by climate change, scientists say
Event Summary: The water levels at Lake Mead have dropped more than 130 feet since 2000 and is approaching the threshold of a shortage for the first time since it was created. Recent BoR projections predict a shortage in 2022, forcing the largest mandatory water cutbacks yet in Arizona, Nevada, and Mexico. Scientists call for collective action and collaboration akin to the 2019 Drought Contingency Plans as the Biden Administration responds with the formation of a new interagency working group to address the drought.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, All Water Users, Agriculture, Development, Tribal Nations
Comments: Event is release of projections predicting shortages/cutbacks and calls for colllective action and collaboration.

Article Title: SOAK IT IN
Event Summary: A member of the board of the Central Arizona Project writes an op ed encouraging community members to educate themselves about the ongoing drought and the connection of Lake Mead levels to central Arizona water supplies.  They call for community education and awareness initiatives (i.e., billboards) and instill a sense of civil responsibility.
Stakeholders: All Water Users, State Government, Irrigation Districts
Comments: Event is board member encouraging the public to push for education initiatives and inform themselves on the drought crisis.

Article Title: Hoover Dam faces epic drought test; Reservoir levels are near lowest point since Lake Mead was filled
Event Summary: The BoR takes the author on a tour of Hoover Dam as Lake Mead water levels are at record lows. The BoR talks about the their responsibility to communicate water forecasts to states, water districts, tribes and other entities along the river so that they can effectively plan for drought and the possibility of water cutbacks to keep water levels in the lake at minimum viable power levels.
Stakeholders: All Water Users, Federal Government
Comments: No direct stakeholder interaction

Article Title: Gov. John Hickenlooper's legacy of water
Event Summary: Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper prepares to leave office amid a legacy of nagivating water issues and leading the developement of a state water plan. While the Governor is often celebrated for this landmark effort, the plan is critized by members of the state senate for its lack of specific objects in how to achieve conservation goals and establish additional storage. Specifically, the state has yet to identify a funding source of the implementation of urban and ag conservation efforts.
Stakeholders: State Government, All Water Users, Agriculture, Environmental Groups
Comments: Event is voicing of critisim from members of the state legislature who state that the Governor's state water plan increased cooperative efforts in state but also has no "teeth" (funding) dedicated to complete initiatives.

Article Title: High hopes for Colorado River Compact plan
Event Summary: States reach an agreement on the 2019 Drought Contingency Plan. The seven CRB states send a letter to Congress requesting the legislation necessary to implement hte new plan. The Imperial Irrigation District decries the plan as leaving out the Salton Sea and states that if the plan moves forward without the district, that serves to elimiate the river's largest single water use and ignores the environmental challenges of the Salton Sea. The district accuses states of acting as though getting the plan done is more important than getting it right.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, Irrigation Districts, All Water Users, Agriculture
Comments: Event is interaction between the Imperial Irrigation District and state planners with district stating that Salton Sea concerns were left out of plan.

Article Title: Too much salt
Event Summary: The next round of funding is announced for the Colorado River Basin Salinity Control Program (NRCS) which enables private landowners to rebuilt their irrigation systems to maximize efficiency and prevent increasing salinity levels in the Corado River.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, Agriculture
Comments: Event is call for stakeholder participation from NRCS/governmental or monetary assistance from NRCS to local agriculturalists.

Article Title: Will water cuts be enough to save Lake Mead?; It's too soon to tinker with key parts of the Colorado River Compact. For now, our best bet may be to temporarily extend the Drought Contingency Plan
Event Summary: The BoR releases a forecast predicting that Lake Mead will drop another 42 feet in the next five years, threatening power generation and release for downstream water users in California and Arizona. States start to consider if further reductions will need to occur by 2026 with implementation of new Drought Contingency Plan efforts called "DCP Plus" as planners consider the effects of climate change in addition to human water use. The op-ed author (former AZ Governor and DOI Secretary) calls for more adjustements to the amount of timing of DCP reductions and an extnesion of the DCP for another 10 years.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, All Water Users
Comments: Event is release of op ed piece from former AZ Governor/DOI Secretary Bruce Babbit calling for state planners to consider the extenstion of the DCP and the condieration of plan adjustements.

Article Title: Utah among 7 states agreeing on plan to manage drought-stricken Colorado River system
Event Summary: Several state drought contingency plans are released to the public. California agrees to soften the blow by voluntarily reducing its Colorado River use by about 6 percent if conditions are bad enough. Several applaud the level of collaboration that exists between states.
Stakeholders: State Government, All Water Users
Comments: Event is interaction between California and other basin states/pledge of voluntary cutbacks in the event of shortages.

Article Title: Colorado pushes its use of West's major river to the limit, new study shows
Event Summary: A new study is released by the Utah Rivers Council showing that continued water development in Colorado will force the state to run an annual Colorado River water deficit that could worsen if water resources continue to dwindle. The report states that current development proposals do not take into consideration unused tribal water rights and the state's obligation to send water downriver to Mexico.
Stakeholders: NGO, Environmental Groups, State Government, Development
Comments: Interaction is between environmental groups (NGOs) and Colorado State development groups with the NGOs criticizing new water projects of inadequate planning with regard to tribal water rights and downstream flows to Mexico.

Article Title: Colorado River basin states cobble together water agreement
Event Summary: Colorado Senator Cory Gardner attends the first congressional hearing since the seven CRB states signed the Drought Contingency Plan. During the meeting he applaudes the states for coordinated a plan that voluntarily cuts their water usage to prevent federal government intervention. Gardner also warns of the effect increased water demand, drought, and climate change will have on Lake Mead water levels.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, All Water Users
Comments: Interaction is between CO state rep and other states/federal government. Voicing approval of agreement.

Newspaper: The Associated Press State & Local Wire
Article Title: Water settlement goes before Navajo lawmakers
Event Summary: Navajo lawmakers are set to consider a bill to settle the tribe's (and Hopi Nation's) water rights in the lower Colorado River Basin in northeastern Arizona. The settlement would give the Navajo Nation 31,000 acre-feet of water a year from the Colorado River, the unappropriated surface flows from the Little Colorado, and nearly unlimited access to water beneath the reservation. Tribal lawmaker LoneTree criticizes the proposal and urges lawmakers to vote down the bill, stating that more tribal input is needed and that the settlement forfeights Navajo water rights for the benefit of other water users.
Stakeholders: Navajo Nation, Hopi Tribe, State Government, Federal Government, All Water Users
Comments: Chose to focus on the intratribal interaction as the event. There was dissent among at least one tribal lawmaker and the call for more tribal community input reads as exclusionary processes.

Article Title: Tribal water study outlines challenges for Navajo
Event Summary: Article describes the release of The Tribal Water Study, completed under partnership with BOR and the Ten Tribes, which documents how the Partnership Tribes use their water, how future development could occur and what impacts might be to the Colorado River System. It also lays out challenges and opportunities for discussion and exploration. It describes the water users and primary uses historically, points out potential conflicts and shortfalls to expect, and the difficulties the Tribes have had establishing infrastructure to deliver water they need, and the injustice of paying incredibly inflated rates for water as compared to anywhere in the US while being among the poorest peoples. In addition their existing infrastructure costs outweigh revenue and are in need of expensive upkeep and modernization.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, Ute Mountain Tribe, Southern Ute Indian Tribe, Ute Indian Tribe, Jicarilla Apache Nation, Navajo Nation, Fort Mojave Indian Tribe, Colorado River Indian Tribes, Chemehuevi Indian Tribe, Quechan Indian Tribe, Cocopah Indian Tribe, Private Citizens, Private Utility, Water Managers
Comments: Positive collaborations

Article Title: 5-year study consolidates county maps; Homeowners now in flood plain may need enhanced insurance
Place: Animas River including Junction and Lightner Creeks from Bakers Bridge to the New Mexico line, La Plata RIver from Mayday to the New Mexico State line, Vellecito Creek, Pine River from Vallecito to the Southern Ute Indian Tribe reservation south of Bayfield, Florida River,
Event Summary: The event is that La Plata County has adopted newly consolidated and updated flood plain maps and land use codes to better inform residents about the need for flood insurance, which will help save property and lives, inform planning (restrictive development standards) and so forth.
Stakeholders: County Government, Water Managers, Federal Government, Business, Residents, Business
Comments: Coded it a 0 based on the fact that there is no mention of conflict despite the potential added costs to homes' insurance rates which are placed into flood areas which were not before.

Article Title: Colorado pushes its use of West's major river to the limit, new study shows; Utah Rivers Council found that diversion and climate change could worsen limited water resources across seven Western states
Event Summary: Utah Rivers Council released a report (A Future on Borrowed Time, 2021) using BOR data that assessed how reduced flows in the Colorado River from climate change affect water allocation. Despite the decrease of annual flows of water in the Colorado River, upper basin states have continued to use water without adjusting for the decrease. Colorado is also continuing with construction of new divergence water projects which are declared irresponsible and ignorant given they already have a deficit of about 500,000 acre-feet. The impacts are severe downstream for their overuse. In 2022 Mexico, Arizona, and Nevada will see water cuts, but Colorado remains unaffected. The upper basin is behind in reducing use to sustain the future.
Stakeholders: State Government, Tribes Of The State Of Colorado, NGO, Federal Government, Mexico, Other Interest Groups, Environmentalists, Private Citizens, Water Managers, Developers, Business
Comments: Here is the report that the article is talking about https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5a46b200bff2007bcca6fcf4/t/61b678ae088ad458939d92c4/1639348411964/The+Colorado+River+A+Future+on+Borrowed+Time.pdf

Article Title: 7 states finish deal for drought; Congress must now enact plan into law
Event Summary: The State representatives met in Phoenix (behind closed doors, no public observing) and agreed to cuts to water deliveries amidst ongoing shortages. Conflict because California's Imperial Irrigation Distrct was left out of the deal even though they control the largest single share of water, Conflict for exclusions of major players, crises as the Salton Sea area has a growing health crisis brewing with dust from the drying landscape increasing asthma issues and causing waterfowl suffering.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Private Citizens, Environmentalists, Conservation, Agriculture
Comments: Suggested -1 for intensity due to the very obvious dissent about the process from the Imperial Irrigation District. Those involved in the negotiations and those describing it suggest they were made, but no real hints on what went on behind closed doors.

Article Title: Arizona is very close to triggering water war
Event Summary: As of this writing, Arizona had yet to sign onto the Drought Contingency plan (a basin-wide pan) which was held up due to internal AZ state legislature issues, described in the article as 'caught up in special interest demands'. There is a conflict in that some interested groups are overstepping their authorities in dealing with/negotiating water issues, and there are conflicts between parties about historic agreements made over water that are no longer realistic (Pinal agricultural districts being asked to change a plan before 2030 when it is set to phase out using water deliveries from the Colorado River and instead use more local groundwater). The crisis in the article is that if the state does not sign on to the plan soon, they may be left out and enter a water war.
Stakeholders: State Government, Private Citizens, Agriculture, Irrigation Districts, Conservation District
Comments: I went with intensity value based on the fact that this is an op-ed from an informed audience (former interior secretary) who is warning AZ of what will happen if they don't sign onto the Drought Contingency Plan

Article Title: Green River water diversion proposal draws protests
Place: The application for Utah water rights requests 55,000 acre feet of water from the Green River with two pump stations located five miles from the Colorado state line in Dagget County, Utah, on Bureau of Land Management land. The water would then run through a hydroelectric facility before being piped nearly 500 miles northeast into Wyoming and then south down the Colorado Front Range
Event Summary: Event is that many are upset (article specifically discusses a statement from Colorado River Water Conservation District but mentions many others) and have written letters protesting a permit from a private investor, who is attemtping to buy water from the Green River in Utah and pipe it to the Colorado Front Range where future water shortages are anticipated to be a problem. This is speculation and supposed to be denied on that fact. The District posits that it would exacerbate supply problems and that there has not been enough environmental analysis for the impact of the plan to move water out of the Green Basin, and that it has not worked collaboratively enough to addres future water needs across the Green River and Colorado River basins.
Stakeholders: State Government, Water Conservation District, Business, Federal Government
Comments: Found the date for the permit, in this publication https://www.biologicaldiversity.org/programs/public_lands/rivers/pdfs/Water-Horse-Million-Utah-State-Eng-Decision-2020.pdf

Article Title: Bennet and Romney raft Colorado River amid historic drought; Ranches in Southwest Colorado suffering from water shortages
Event Summary: Senators rafted the Colorado River to draw attention to ongoing drought and water shortage issues, increasing hazards, and the impacts in the long term to expect from climate change. Event Summary: There has been compromise/agreement with the Central Arizona Project and other water users to put forward a plan for managing diminishing water supplies to the State of Arizona legislature for a vote. Article Title: Colorado Editorial Roundup

Event Summary: HB 2338 on hold in the state legislature in Arizona, which would allow for the buying and selling of water. Communities like Yuma are concerned because the water provides the ability to grow billions of dollars in food, fiber, production that is the local economy.

As smoke billowed over the headwaters, the wildfires raised warning signs of how profoundly climate change is altering the watershed, and how the symptoms of heat-driven drying are cascading down the heavily used river - with stark implications for the entire region, from Colorado's ranchland pastures to the suburbs of Phoenix

Article Title: Group rallies against Navajo Water Rights Settlement
Event Summary: The water war is on. The San Juan Agricultural Water Users Association is rallying local water users at 7 tonight to educate users about the ongoing Navajo Water Rights Settlement. The organization is the most represented local group that is fighting the settlement, but it is hoping to recruit as many interested advocates as possible. "We stand to lose a whole lot if this goes through," said association president Mike Sullivan of the settlement. The agreement, which was signed in December by former Navajo Nation President Joe Shirley and Secretary of Interior Ken Salazar, is a battle that has been fought since the 1960s, though it's rooted in documentation dating back to the 1800s.

Article Title: A quest for water: Whose water is it?
Event Summary: State Engineer Jerry Olds, seeing Wayne County perilously close to the deadline for putting its 50,000 acre-feet per year of Colorado River to use, last year approved Vetere's request for one of the largest water-right transfers in recent state history. The rancher's quest for water comes at a time when water needs increasingly are clashing with reality: The state has doled out 180,000 rights to tap rivers and dig wells, but there's just not enough water to honor them all. Vetere now can draw on the Green River - about 60 miles upstream from where the right exists - for Wayne County's Fremont River allocation and may irrigate more than 16,000 acres across three counties. And Olds, willing to get creative to solve some of Utah's most vexing water problems, reckons the rancher's plan might set an example for how Utah can keep its share of Colorado River water at a time when big downstream states are facing shortages.
Stakeholders: County Government, Agriculture, State Government

Article Title: Long-term plan for Colorado River water won't be sealed before Trump takes office
Event Summary: A long-term plan for protecting Lake Mead and preventing severe shortages in deliveries of Colorado River water to Arizona and two other states won't be approved before the Obama administration ends, throwing more uncertainty into the outlook. While the three states keep discussing a drought contingency plan, Arizona water officials say they've reached general agreement with water users here for a shorter-term fix for Lake Mead's chronic declines. A short term plan is in place, hoping that with agreement amongst the major players, the Trump administration will not change it drastically. The short term plan will cost users more money however.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government

Article Title: Drought deepens strain on a dwindling Colorado
Event Summary: The drought gripping Utah, Southern California and the rest of the Southwest this century shows no sign of ending. Scientists see it as a permanent condition that, despite year-to-year weather variations, will deepen as temperatures rise, snows dwindle, soils bake and fires burn. That's grim news for all of us in the West, perhaps most especially for the 10 million residents along the northern stretch of the Colorado River -- Utah, New Mexico, Wyoming and Colorado -- whose water rights are newer, and therefore junior, to those in Southern California, Nevada and Arizona.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, All Water Users
Comments: There was less of an interaction here and more of a focus on the crises present.

Article Title: Quenching a thirst for development; Western Arizona tribes could lease Colorado River water across state
Event Summary: The 4,500 people of the Mohave, Chemehuevi, Navajo and Hopi tribes who belong to the Colorado River Indian Tribes, or CRIT, are hoping to profit by leasing some of that water to the rest of Arizona for the first time. The plan is filled with complications, legal and logistical. Moving the water from the river to other locations would require costly new infrastructure and cooperation among several water management agencies. But the amount of water is significant enough to help settle water issues across the state, from Tusayan on the rim of the Grand Canyon south to Sierra Vista. And Arizona's growing population is making the tribes' water more valuable by the day.
Stakeholders: Colorado River Indian Tribes, State Government

Article Title: Utah's first N-plant won't float without water rights

Article Title: Colorado River, floodgates open, surges toward the sea - Correction Appended
Event Summary: The Colorado River rushed past the U.S.-Mexican border this week for the first time since the late 1990s, a river reborn and rolling over desert sands on its way to a reunion with the Gulf of California. The planned flood, or "pulse flow," is designed to churn up dry soils and germinate wetland plants whose seeds have long lain dormant as upstream canals and pipes siphoned off the river to Denver, Phoenix, Los Angeles, Baja California Norte and farms throughout the Southwest. The gates at Mexico's Morelos Dam have been opened wide under an international agreement only until May 18, but the waters of the Colorado are expected to regenerate thousands of acres of willows and cottonwoods to shelter migratory birds and revive a former oasis.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, Mexico

Article Title: Grand Canyon may see more 'grand flushes'

The latest of three such floods, unleashed in March 2008, created lasting Colorado River sandbars to benefit fish, wildlife and river-running campers, said this week's report.
Stakeholders: Federal Government

Article Title: Kelly addresses pain of Arizona farmers in hearing on drought

Among those called to testify was Arizona Department of Water Resources Director Tom Buschatzke. He acknowledged the difficult situation Arizona faces, with the state set to lose an allotment of 512,000 acre-feet of water from the Colorado River at the start of 2022, and it could be in line for more cuts in 2023 if water levels don't rebound.  Buschatzke said that his department supports voluntary conservation efforts over mandated cutbacks to water use but said "that will be a heavy lift."

Event Summary: A BoR operations plan is announced that will for the first time slow the flow of water from the Lake Powell reservoir to Lake Mead. Water cuts to Las Vegas are not expected. A Southern California water manager calls for basin states to work together to deal with drought implications and avoid cuts. Similar comments are included from other basin state water managers.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Tribal Nations, Agriculture, All Water Users
Comments: Event is release of BoR plan which impacts Powell and Mead levels. No cuts, but state water managers comment and announce plans for addressing the impacts as a result of plan.

Article Title: 40 Million People Rely on the Colorado River. Its Drying Up Fast
Officials assessing storm damage
Lewis addresses lawmakers about impact of COVID on GRIC
Event Summary: Several tribal leaders from 22 recognized tribes visit the Capitol to talk with legislative leaders on the 27th Annual Indian Nations and Tribes Legislative Day. Topics discussed include water rights, COVID-19 impacts, voting rights, and infrastructure needs. Collaborative water conservation and drought planning efforts are higlighted, such as the 2021 Colorado River Indian Tribes Resiliency Act. At the end of the meeting, tribal leaders thanks the Arizona Legislature and spoke of hopes for continued collaboration to address issues that impact Indigenous communities and the state.
Stakeholders: Navajo Nation, Colorado River Indian Tribe, Gila River Indian Community
Comments: Event is meeting between AZ Legislature and AZ tribes. Meeting not for settlement, but calls for future collaboration are made.

Article Title: Drought not ending, despite all the snow; Lakes Powell, Mead at lowest levels since 1960s
Event Summary: Lake Powell and Mead are at 40% of full capacity, the lowest levels since the 1960s despite above average precip and snowpack levels. Federal officials press CA and AZ to finish their portions of the Drought Contingency Plan while water managers across the lower basin criticize the plan as a mere stopgap that does not address the cause of growing water shortages.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, Water Managers, All Water Users
Comments: Interaction is between federal and state entities, delay in drought contingency planning and feds urging states to finish efforts.

Newspaper: The Associated Press State & Local Wire
Article Title: Price tag focus of northern Ariz. water settlement
Event Summary: A key water rights settlement in Northern Arizona is threatened due to an 800 million dollar price tag and unsteady political climate. An AZ rep has asked Navajo, Hopi, and other negotiators to try to lower the ocst so that the legislation can be introduced to Congress. The settlement would quantify Navjo's rights to water from the lower Colorado River basin, develop piplines to deliver water to tribal communities, and settle Hopi's claims. It would also end a 2003 lawsuit the Navajo filed against the DOI.
Stakeholders: Navajo Nation, Hopi Tribe, State Government, Federal Government, Water Managers, Agriculture, All Water Users
Comments: Event is delay in settlement negotiation between state and triabl entities due to cost.

Article Title: Ducey signs drought plan; Pinal farm details prove contentious
Event Summary: After a BoR rep threathens federal intervention, AZ Governor Ducey signs the drought contingency plan. Plan is signed despite objections from some legislators who cite the lack of climate change and conservation planning and question allowing Pinal County farmers to pump groundwater through new tax-payer paid infrastructure. Still, legislators agree that plan needed to be signed ASAP to avoid federal intervention.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Agriculture, Tribal Nations, All Water Users
Comments: Event is signing of drought contingency plan by AZ governor/settlement despite objections.

Article Title: Animas River Stakeholders disband after 25 years of cleanup efforts; Group's role fell into doubt after Superfund established outside Silverton
Event Summary: The Animas River Stakeholders Group is disbanded after 25 years of local, state, and federal agencies as well as mining companies worked together to improve the helath of the Animas River amid heavy-metal loading from legacy mines. WQ has degraded due to recent mining projects and the group's role has been questioned after a Superfund site was established outside of Silverton. Group efforts had recently been hindered by potentially liability costs for large remediation projects that are stated to be better suited for EPA.
Stakeholders: Private Citizens, Environmental Groups, Local Government, State Government, Federal Government, Mining
Comments: Event is dissoulution of stakeholder group due to potential liability costs enforced by federal government and public perception after Superfund was established near local mining site.

Article Title: GSL selenium standard is a product of study
Event Summary: Op ed from Utah Division of WQ Director disputing the recent Salt Lake Tribute editoral comment that the new selenium standard set by the Utah Water Quality Board for the Great Salt Lake is too high. Author states that stakeholders were given a voice and that the standard is supported by science and fulfulls the obligation of the Department of Water Quality to protect the biological health of the lake.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, Environment, All Water Users
Comments: Event is op ed piece from Director of hte Utah Division of Water Quality addressing public criticism of new WQ standard.

Article Title: SALT RIVER'S LOST RUNOFF HELPS STATE, AFTER ALL;MEXICO'S WINDFALL SPARES LAKE MEAD
Event Summary: Storm runoff thought to be lost after it was diverted down the Salt River last month will be released from a flood-control dam to meet US obligations to Mexico, reducing the amount of water that has to be drawn from Lake Mead. The US Army Corps of Enginners agree to work with state and federal agencies, including the Central Arizona Project, on the timing of the releases from both Painted Rock and Alamo dams to deliver adequate supplies and avoid large turbidity levels.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Irrigation Districts, Mexico, All Water Users
Comments: Event is agreement between Army Corps and other agencies to time releases to deliver obligation to Lake Mead and Mexico.

Article Title: At Canyon, water battle rages anew
Event Summary: After formal protests were ignored, the Superintendent of Grand Canyon National Park writes a memo for the Washington Post accusing his bosses of disregarding science in preparing for an artificial flood designed to reverse some of the damaging effects of Glen Canyon Dam on the canyon and Colorado River. He describes the environmental review conducted as one of the worst he's ever seen. Conservation groups sue the DOI, accusing the project of being worked to appease power providers instead of fisheries and habitat. Power providers worry about the effects of releases on power production for poorer communities and lobby for officials to limit events.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Environmental Groups, Environment, All Water Users
Comments: Event is submission of formal complaint memo from park superindendent accusing federal gov of disregarding science and conducting a faulty EA.

Article Title: Alder: A new set of negotiations need for The Colorado River Compact
Event Summary: An op ed written by the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs at the University of Utah disputing a previous editoral written by Senator McCain suggesting that a revisitation of the Colorado River Compact would be costly and create conflict among the CRB states. Author suggests that strategic amendments to the Colorado River Compact could prevent rather than generate conflict, correct past mistakes, and address issues that were beyong consideration in 1922. Author stresses the importance of climate change, tribal representation, and considerations of impacts to the environment/fisheries due to water development.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, Environment, Tribal Nations, Environmental Groups, Mexico, All Water Users
Comments: Event is letter written by dean disputing comments made by senetor and urging collaboration among basin states.

Article Title: COLORADO RIVER STATES ADD HISTORIC CHAPTER IN WATER USE;THE ISSUE: DROUGHT PLANNING
Event Summary: Op ed written by paper editors applauding efforts of the seven CRB states to craft a plan on how the Colorado River should be managed in times of drought. The plan details conservation measures and guidelines to manage water elevation levels at Lake Mead and Powell and puts in place triggers that would lead to DOI involvement.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Irrigation Districts, All Water Users
Comments: Event is op ed written by editoral board applauding collaboration between basin states and feds.

Article Title: Experts predict low San Juan County river flows this summer
Event Summary: The Colorado Basin River Forecast Center predicts the San Juan River will flow at 44% of its average levels from April to July, prompting comments from water commissioners on the implicications the Navajor Water Rights Settlement of 2013 will have on competition for water resources.
Stakeholders: Navajo Nation, State Government, Water Managers, All Water Users
Comments: Event is release of forecast which prompts water managers to warn of Navajo settlement impacts to water conflict.

Article Title: As the river runs dry Crisis on tap How users respond to dwindling Colorado River resources will decide whether the Southwest can sustain its growth
Event Summary: The Arizona Republic newspaper examines the stresses of climate change and population growth on water supplies in the Southwest. The article outlines conservation plans throughout the CRB, including changes in irrigation and municipal regulations on water use. Article also dives into agreements made between CAP and the BoR to keep water in Lake Mead.
Stakeholders: Federal Government, State Government, Local Government, All Water Users
Comments: Article has no impact to stakeholder interactions.

Article Title: Officials: Arizona will miss US deadline for key water plan
Event Summary: The state of Arizona announced they won't have their drought plan finished by the federal government deadline. On the same day, Arizona House Speaker Rusty Bowers put his proposed alterations to Arizona's "use it or lose it" water rights law on hold after it was objected to by the Gila River Indian Community Governor Lewis, who suggested if the changes move forward they would pull out of the AZ drought contingency planning efforts.
Stakeholders: State Government, Federal Government, All Water Users
Comments: Scored a -2 based on the disagreements among the Gila River Indian Community and the House Speaker in regards to the changes to the water rights laws.

Article Title: Water officials consider action for worst case; Suppliers look at consequences of a call on Colorado River rights
Event Summary: Board members of the Southwestern Waer Conservation District and the Colorado River Water Association took up the discussion about what would happen if AZ, NV and CA demanded their full share of CO River water in time of drought or for new uses at a meeting in Durango. The concerns discussed the agricultural interests of about 1 million acre-feet of water in the Western Slope, and how Senior users may be compensated financially for allowing junior users to take water. The use by junior-right users must be critical, and this is one area of potential future conflicts, about what is critical use.
Stakeholders: NGO, Conservation District, Agriculture, Business
Comments: Scored based on the fact that the discussion was exploring what would happen if a downstream water call put stakeholders in this place, what choices would have to be made. There isn't a true conflict at this time but potential conflicts were foreshadowed between agricultural and other uses.

Article Title: Rangely hosts Colorado River District event
Issue Type: Drought; Water quality; Water rights more generally; Infrastructure issues
Event Summary: The event is a 'State of the River' event involving Western Slope stakeholders from the White River Area. (Rio Blanco Conservancy District, Colorado Department of Natural Resources, Colorado River District, Rio Blanco Water District, White River and Douglas Creek Conservation Districts) where news "ranged from bad to good" from across a half dozen presentations about the most recent river flow activity as well as the major events that supply water and how those are changing. Population increases are expected to impact water availability in the future even as each 1-degree increase in temperature will reduce streamflow between 3-9% and impact water quality. A range of projects were described to aid in protecting future water availability and water quality to the region.
Stakeholders: Conservancy District, State Government, All Water Users, County Government, Water District, Environment
Comments: No true conflicts explored at this event. Purely status/updates delivered and facts explored.

Article Title: California water district lawsuit threatens drought plan: of~ cial
Place: State of Arizona, State of California
Event Summary: The event is that California's Imperial Irrigation District is suing to block California's Metropolitan Water District from signing legal papers to make it part of the Drought Contingency Plan. This threatens the entire multi-state Drought Contingency Plan. There are impacts to Arizona's water users, especially Pinal county farmers, who have the lowest claim on Colorado River water.
Stakeholders: All Water Users, Agriculture, State Government, Federal Government, Irrigation Districts, Water Managers
Comments: Scored based on the fact that the event is active litigation.

Article Title: Scientists want to flush water past Glen Canyon Dam again
Event Summary: Dept of Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne signed a final record of decision in response to water sharing needs between the states to support a healthy river ecosystem, discouraging invasive species, creating safe harbors for native endangered species and improving habitat along the river with high flow experiments using adaptive management techniques.
Stakeholders: All Water Users, Environment
Comments: Scored 5 based on the agreement to protect the river ecosystem being formally signed in this event.

Article Title: Arizona plan could devastate Pinal farmers
Event Summary: The event is Arizona signing off on the Drought Contingency Plan.
Stakeholders: Agriculture, State Government, Federal Government
Comments: Agreement signed and cooperation on all  sides. There was contention mentioned, keeping the intensity score from being a 5
